diagnosis.score_summary: With an alignment score of 26/100, the brand is suffering from a severe identity crisis. The direct-to-consumer site (WWW) presents a serious, clinical expert focused on scientific proof, while the Amazon presence (PDP) projects a trendy, accessible K-beauty influencer focused on aesthetic glow. This fundamental conflict across core markers like Focus, Positioning, and Messaging confuses customers and erodes brand equity.

truth_1.headline: The Professor vs. The Pitchman
truth_1.gap_description: WWW focuses on 'Science Education,' aiming to build trust through clinical explanations. The PDP focuses on 'Lifestyle Aesthetic,' aiming to build desire through aspirational visuals and emotional promises. You are teaching a class on one channel and throwing a party on the other.
truth_1.evidence: [FOCUS] WWW: 'Science Education' — "Driven by research. Proven by results." vs. PDP: 'Lifestyle Aesthetic' — "The blended texture is irresistible — Complete the ultimate glass glow look"
truth_1.why_matters: This schizophrenia confuses the customer's purchase motivation. Are they making a rational, evidence-based decision or an emotional, identity-driven one? A confused customer is a customer who doesn't convert.
truth_1.the_hard_choice: Your brand's core purpose is unclear. Is it to educate or to inspire? The data demands a choice: Option A is to embrace the high-conversion, desire-driven 'Lifestyle Aesthetic' of the PDP and redesign the website to match. Option B is to discipline the PDP, forcing it to adopt the 'Science Education' focus to build long-term authority. A brand that tries to be both a textbook and a magazine will be read by no one.

truth_2.headline: Investment Piece vs. Viral Find
truth_2.gap_description: On its own site, the brand positions itself as 'The Scientific Miracle,' a premium 'Investment Piece.' On Amazon, it's 'The Clean Essentialist,' an accessible, 'Elevated Everyday' product priced for volume. This is a classic prestige vs. masstige conflict.
truth_2.evidence: [POSITIONING] WWW: 'The Scientific Miracle' — "professional-grade skincare" vs. PDP: 'The Clean Essentialist' — "Best Sellers Rank: #9 in Face Moisturizers"
truth_2.why_matters: A customer who sees the $16 'viral' product on Amazon will never believe the 'professional-grade investment' story on your website. This conflict directly attacks your pricing power and destroys any claim to being a premium brand.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: You are a luxury brand online and a bargain brand on the world's biggest marketplace. This is unsustainable. Option A: Accept that the market sees you as an accessible trend and re-write your website to embrace the high-volume, 'masstige' positioning. Option B: Overhaul the Amazon PDP—raising the price and changing the creative—to reflect the premium 'Scientific Miracle' you claim to be. You can't be a bargain and a breakthrough at the same time.

truth_3.headline: Solving Problems vs. Selling Dreams
truth_3.gap_description: The WWW messaging is that of 'The Problem Solver,' using rational arguments about fixing skin concerns. The PDP acts as 'The Promise Maker,' using evocative language to sell the dream of a 'glass glow look.' One channel offers a prescription, the other offers a fantasy.
truth_3.evidence: [MESSAGING] WWW: 'The Problem Solver' — "enhances elasticity, firmness, and resilience" vs. PDP: 'The Promise Maker' — "Plump Up Your Glow!"
truth_3.why_matters: This messaging conflict creates deep distrust. A customer doesn't know whether to believe the logical claim or the magical promise, so they end up believing neither. The brand's core value proposition becomes incoherent.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: Your brand is speaking two different languages to the same customer. One is the language of the lab, the other is the language of the runway. You must choose one. Option A: Embrace the emotional, promise-driven language that is likely driving conversion on Amazon and update the website's clinical copy. Option B: Force the Amazon listing to adopt the rational, problem-solving language to maintain your clinical authority. A solution fixes a problem; a promise sells a dream. You must decide which business you are in.

truth_4.headline: The Accidental Pragmatist
truth_4.gap_description: Both channels successfully signal 'The Pragmatist,' meaning customers feel smart for buying your product. However, this alignment is a fragile coincidence. On WWW, 'smart' means choosing proven science. On PDP, 'smart' means choosing a popular bestseller with 5,000 reviews.
truth_4.evidence: [SELF-EXPRESSION] WWW: 'The Pragmatist' — "Driven by research. Proven by results." vs. PDP: 'The Pragmatist' — "Best Sellers Rank: #9...5,029 global ratings"
truth_4.why_matters: The brand's 'smart choice' identity is built on two different foundations: durable scientific proof (WWW) and fickle social proof (PDP). If a competitor takes the #1 bestseller spot on Amazon, the reason to believe evaporates, as there is no underlying scientific authority to fall back on.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: Your brand's success with pragmatists is an accident, not a strategy. You must now choose which type of pragmatist you serve. Option A: Fully commit to the social proof game, investing in tactics to maintain viral momentum and bestseller status. Option B: Fortify the PDP with the scientific proof points from the website to convert trend-followers into true believers with a more durable reason to buy. Popularity is rented, but authority is owned. You are currently paying rent on Amazon.

truth_5.headline: The Story Is Better On Amazon
truth_5.gap_description: Both channels tell a consistent story of 'The Lab Breakthrough,' an institutional science narrative. However, the PDP proves this story is more compelling when wrapped in an energetic, emotional, and benefit-driven package. Your own website is the most boring place to hear your brand's origin story.
truth_5.evidence: [NARRATIVE] Both channels signal 'The Lab Breakthrough'. WWW's execution is sterile: "we experiment with various ingredients and formulas". PDP's is exciting: "Innovative Triple Collagen Formula".
truth_5.why_matters: You have successfully identified a core narrative that works on both channels. But the superior performance and engagement on the PDP proves that your DTC channel is leaving money on the table by presenting this story in a cold, clinical manner.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: Your core story is solid, but your website is telling it like a lecture while Amazon is telling it like a blockbuster movie trailer. The market has shown you which version it prefers. Option A: Keep the website as a formal, clinical archive for the purists, conceding that it will never be your primary growth engine. Option B: Adopt the energetic, benefit-driven storytelling from the PDP to make your own website the most compelling destination for your brand. Even the most brilliant science needs a soul to be heard. Your Amazon page found it first.

marker_1.so_what: The brand's core purpose shifts from clinical healing (WWW) to aesthetic empowerment (PDP), creating fundamental confusion about its promise.

marker_2.so_what: The brand is a selective, tech-focused vanguard on its site but a mass-market democratizer on Amazon, a conflict that undermines any claim to exclusivity.

marker_3.so_what: The brand's values are split between 'Radical Transparency' (WWW) and 'Safety First' (PDP), confusing whether the core value is high-performance or gentle care.

marker_4.so_what: A premium 'Scientific Miracle' on WWW clashes with an accessible 'Clean Essentialist' on PDP, directly eroding pricing power and perceived value.

marker_5.so_what: The personality splits from a 'Reliable Expert' (WWW) to a 'Trendsetter' (PDP), making the brand feel like a serious doctor who moonlights as a party promoter.

marker_6.so_what: The archetype mix is completely different, shifting from a Sage/Hero (Philosopher) on WWW to a Magician/Caregiver (Performer) on PDP. This is a total personality transplant.

marker_7.so_what: The tone shifts from a dry 'Clinical Authority' on WWW to an energetic 'Hype Beast' on PDP, creating a jarring and untrustworthy voice.

marker_8.so_what: The visual identity is incoherent, moving from an inferred sterile 'Pharma-Code' (WWW) to a warm, soft 'Earthy Organic' (PDP), creating sensory dissonance.

marker_9.so_what: Messaging is split between rational 'Problem Solving' (WWW) and emotional 'Promise Making' (PDP), weakening the core reason to believe.

marker_10.so_what: The 'Lab Breakthrough' narrative is a point of strength, providing a consistent, albeit sterile, origin story across both channels.

marker_11.so_what: Key selling points diverge from 'Derm-Validation' (WWW) to 'Formula Purity' (PDP), confusing whether proof comes from doctors or 'free-from' lists.

marker_12.so_what: The USP shifts from being a 'Specialist' with proprietary tech (WWW) to a 'Tech Engineer' in a broader category (PDP), diluting its unique positioning.

marker_13.so_what: The content focus is diametrically opposed: 'Science Education' (WWW) vs. 'Lifestyle Aesthetic' (PDP). This is the root of the brand's identity crisis.

marker_14.so_what: Both channels consistently promise 'Correction' of aesthetic issues like firmness and tone, creating a clear and reliable functional benefit for the customer.

marker_15.so_what: Emotional benefits are misaligned, offering 'Confidence' from solving a problem (WWW) versus 'Intelligence' from making a savvy choice (PDP).

marker_16.so_what: Both channels align on 'The Pragmatist' self-expression, a key strength, but for dangerously different reasons (science vs. social proof).

marker_17.so_what: Social benefits are misaligned, offering entry to a 'Knowledge Club' (WWW) versus the safety of a mainstream choice (PDP), confusing the brand's social currency.
